fields.descriptive_line: Three fragments of a plaster cast of a spandrel. When it was acquired, this object was originally one of four spandrels surrounding a medallion carved with an arabesque design. The original ornament was above the smaller doorway of the Wikala (caravanserai) of Sultan Qa’itbay, near the mosque of al-Azhar in Cairo, built 1477.
fields.physical_description: Plaster cast made from locally available Egyptian building plaster, which has a pinkish tone. The surface has been patinated.

fields.uncertainty: Plaster casts were installed in the maison arabe built for St Maurice between 1872 and 1879 by the F

fields.public_access_description:
Plaster cast of a spandrel, now in three fragments. When it was acquired, this object was originally one of four spandrels surrounding a medallion carved with an arabesque design. The other objects in the set were deaccessioned in the 1930s.

The original ornament from which this was cast was located above the smaller entrance doorway of the Wikala (caravanserai) of Sultan Qa’itbay, near the mosque of al-Azhar in Cairo, built in 1477. Plaster casts from a variety of historic monuments across Cairo, especially those built during the reign of Sultan Qa’itbay (r.1468-96), were made to decorate the ‘maison arabe’ of the French aristocrat, the Comte Gaston de St Maurice (1831-1905), which was built for him between 1872 and 1879. 

St Maurice lived in Cairo for twenty years, serving as equerry to the Khedive (Ottoman governor) of Egypt. During that period, he accumulated a large collection of historic objects from Islamic Egypt, dating especially from the 14th-16th centuries but also including some 19th-century objects. The V&A acquired about 200 objects from St Maurice collection in 1884.
fields.bibliography:
<u>List of Objects in the Art Division, South Kensington Museum acquired during the Year 1884.</u> London: Eyre and Spottiswoode, 1885. pp. 97
Mercedes Volait, <u>Maisons de France au Caire: le remploi de grans décors mamelouks et ottomans dans une architecture modernes</u> (Cairo: Institut Français d’Archéologie Orientales, 2012)
fields.history_note:
Registered description: Plaster casts. Medallion carved with arabesque design, and four spandrils, from above the smaller doorway of the Wekáleh of Káit-Bey at Cairo. The original, Saracenic. 15th century.

Bought from the collection of Gaston de St Maurice (1831-1905). Plaster casts numbered 1020-1884 to 1046-1884 were bought for a total of £60.

Originally 1020 to 1020D were acquired. Parts A, B, C and D were written off (destroyed) in 1934. See RP/33/2518.

The V&A holds approximately 200 objects from the collection of the Comte Gaston de St Maurice (1831-1905). St Maurice was a French aristocrat working in Cairo for some 20 years as equerry to the Khedive (Ottoman governor) of Egypt. During that period, St Maurice accumulated a large collection of historic objects from Islamic Egypt, dating especially from the 14th-16th centuries but also including some 19th-century objects. His tastes ranged widely and his collection included works of art from Syria, Iran, India, East Asia, as well as Europe. These objects were installed, some of them as furnishings, in the maison arabe built for him between 1872 and 1879 by the French architect Ambroise Baudry (1838-1906), who designed several houses for prominent French ex-patriates in Egypt. Part of the decoration of St Maurice’s house included plaster casts taken from a variety of historic buildings across Cairo, especially those built during the reign of Sultan Qa’itbay (r.1468-96). 

St Maurice exhibited his collection at the 1878 Paris Exposition, where it was seen and its quality commented on by curators from the South Kensington Museum (now the V&A). After the exhibition, St Maurice’s collection remained in Paris, on deposit in the Musée des Arts Décoratifs. Due to the increasing political instability in Egypt, culminating with the British occupation (in 1882), St Maurice tried to sell his collection to the South Kensington Museum. The price was considered too high, but part of the collection was received on loan in 1883, the remainder staying in Paris at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs. Eventually in 1884, the loaned objects from St Maurice were bought by South Kensington. Stanley Lane-Poole (1854-1931), Arabist and external advisor to South Kensington on ‘Saracenic art’, considered this collection to be “of the greatest value and rarity”.
fields.historical_context_note: This object was copied in the Museum and given the number Repro.1884-821 to G. This reproduction was recorded as being on loan to the Royal Scottish Museum according to nominal file (12/12/21), although parts B and C were "apparently still here" when this note was made in the Repro registers (undated).
